docs.title: Set a separate ssh key for one or more repo
docs.text:
While adding your machine to github via ssh, we followed github's guide line

However, we can also set up one or more ssh keys for one or more repos.

This can be handy in different scenarios. For example, say for the default setup I have generated ssh key with a passkey. So, for every push/pull action I have to authenticate using that passkey. Now I have a specific repository where I don't want this behavior, rather don't use any passkey at all. To achieve this we can do this:

Run:

ssh-keygen -t ed25519 -f ~/.ssh/id_newID -N ""
  • This creates a new key (id_newID) with no passphrase.
  • The private key is stored in ~/.ssh/id_newID.
  • The public key is stored in ~/.ssh/id_newID.pub.

Now, to push / pull do:

GIT_SSH_COMMAND="ssh -i ~/.ssh/id_newID" git pull

To parsist this behavior, in the repo, do: 

git config core.sshCommand "ssh -i ~/.ssh/id_newID"

docs.title: Add Pdf Pages to a document
docs.text:
To include pages from a pdf to a document you can do:

\usepackage{pdfpages} % To include PDF pages

\begin{document}

...

\includepdf[pages=-]{yourfile.pdf} % The `pages=-` option includes all pages from the PDF


\end{document}

docs.title: add_fonts
docs.text:
# A pseudo scenario
import numpy as np
import matplotlib.pyplot as plt

x = np.arange(0, 100, 0.2)
y = x**2

fig, ax = plt.subplots(figsize=(6, 4))
ax.plot(x, y)

docs.title: Option1: Fonts installed and Setup in global scope
docs.text:
If a particular font is already installed in the development machine/system and for the plotting you want to use it in each plot (ie. global scope)

plt.rcParams['font.family'] = 'Times New Roman'

docs.title: Option2: Fonts installed and Setup Plot Element specific
docs.text:
Tip: Most of the text contatining elements have font or similar keyword argument 

ax.set_title('x vs y', font='Times New Roman')  # Title
ax.set_xlabel('x m/s', font='Arial')  # Label
ax.set_xticks(
    np.arange(0, 100, 20),
    lables=np.arange(0, 100, 20),
    font='Source Code Pro'
)  # tick labels

docs.title: List The font names available to matplotlib
Load a font file without systemwide installation
docs.text:
from matplotlib import font_manager

font_path = "path/to/font.ttf"  
font_props = font_manager.FontProperties(fname=font_path)

ax.plot(x, y)

# Apply the custom font
ax.set_title("x vs y", fontproperties=font_props, fontsize=14)
ax.set_xlabel("X-axis Label", fontproperties=font_props)
ax.set_ylabel("Y-axis Label", fontproperties=font_props)
ax.legend(prop=font_props)

docs.title: Setup Font Size
docs.text:
setup font size of different components in global scope.

import matplotlib as mpl

# Set LaTeX-style font
mpl.rcParams.update({
    "text.usetex": True,
    "font.family": "serif",
    "font.serif": ["Computer Modern"],
    "axes.labelsize": 12,
    "axes.titlesize": 14,
    "legend.fontsize": 12,
    "xtick.labelsize": 12,
    "ytick.labelsize": 12,
})

docs.title: Use figure toolbars
docs.text:
Use matplotlib toolbars in jupyter notebook environment.

matplotlib.use('nbagg')  # For Tool bars in plot

docs.title: Use Latex in global scope
docs.text:
It will display numbers in latex format and also the formula.

plt.rcParams['text.usetex'] = True

docs.title: Format Dates in axis
docs.text:
Let's say I only want to show hours and minutes in the time axis (x-axis)

from matplotlib.dates import DateFormatter

time_format = DateFormatter("%H:%M")

ax.xaxis.set_major_formatter(time_format)
